msContents.summary: Epitaph of a woman named Demetria in trimeters and elegiacs

div.head: Trimeters α
div.p: Katillios, my noble consort, having placed this stone over Demetria, gave me a marvel on account of our august bed. The law of the Fates provides life for the mortals.

div.head: Elegiacs β.
div.p: Even if you have a chest that is fair in appearance, yet my soul is going towards the clear sky from me; I will speak clearly; the divinity gave to the young men to talk as if they were alive with all the people who live on earth after the fate of death. But I was neither singing in a wide choral with virgins, (for indeed, she grieved for me as I was dead, my sorrowful mother), nor did my noble father bring me in the bridal chambers, entering there at his feet as a wedded wife; instead, as I was still unwedded and tender-minded the Golden Fate came and took away the hope of marriage. And my dear father made here with stones a grave, an eternal memorial, for his eighteen year-old girl.
